newsitem.title: INDIA: India says Pakistan "occupies" part of Kashmir.
newsitem.headline: India says Pakistan "occupies" part of Kashmir.

text.p: India on Wednesday restaked a claim over divided Kashmir and said it wanted talks with Islamabad to focus on Pakistan's military "occupation" of part of the region, the cause of two wars between the neighbours.

Foreign Secretary Salman Haider said New Delhi expected talks over Kashmir to focus on Pakistan's support for militancy in the Indian-controlled section of the Himalayan region and not on the legitimacy of Indian rule.

The diplomat, who led the Indian delegation at a round of talks in Islamabad that ended on Monday, denied India had made a landmark concession by agreeing to put Kashmir on an agenda for future talks.
Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said on Monday it was the first time India had recognised Kashmir as disputed. "It is a major breakthrough in Indo-Pakistan relations," Sharif said.

But Haider, who is India's highest-ranking career diplomat, gave a sharply different version which analysts said underscored the deep split that continues to divide the South Asian nations nearly 50 years after they won their independence.

"We have discussed Kashmir, in fact on a number of occasions, and we have also historically taken the position that we do not shy away from discussing Kashmir," Haider told a news conference after returning from Pakistan.
Both Pakistan and India claim the right to rule over Jammu and Kashmir, which has sparked two of the three wars between the two countries.
Pakistan has controlled one third of the region since 1947. Islamabad calls the area under its rule Azad (Free) Kashmir, while India calls it Pakistan Occupied Kashmir (POK).

The remaining two thirds lie within India's Jammu and Kashmir state, where more than 20,000 people have died in violence since a separatist rebellion erupted in 1990. Pakistan denies that it arms and trains guerrillas.
Haider said there were numerous issues to be discussed relating to Jammu and Kashmir at the talks, which are scheduled to resume in September at the foreign secretary level.
"When we talk about the Jammu and Kashmir dispute, there is a juridical element in that," he said.
"We make the point that parts of Jammu and Kashmir are under Pakistani occupation by military force, and that is something that we would certainly discuss."

Haider was asked to comment on whether India, which has long maintained that Pakistan has no rightful claim to any of Jammu and Kashmir, had offered a concession by acknowledging that Kashmir is disputed.
"We have said that there is no dispute in our part of Kashmir, but there are issues relating to POK," he replied.

"We also have other concerns, and these concerns relate to infiltration, support for terrorism, and these are also issues relating to Jammu and Kashmir which we believe need to be addressed," Haider said.
"Our part of Kashmir is going to be discussed, I trust, in the sense that it is subject to infiltration and to support for terrorism."
Asked if India expected the area of Jammu and Kashmir currently under Delhi's control to be discussed as a disputed area, Haider said: "Not in that sense, no."
